etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French pochier, earlier in the sense ‘enclose in a bag’, from poche ‘bag, pocket’

definitions: cook (an egg) without its shell in or over boiling water

examples.text: a breakfast of poached egg and grilled bacon

shortDefinitions: cook egg without its shell in or over boiling water

definitions: cook by simmering in a small amount of liquid

examples.text: poach the salmon in the white wine

shortDefinitions: cook by simmering in small amount of liquid

etymologies: early 16th century (in the sense ‘push roughly together’): apparently related to poke; sense 1 is perhaps partly from French pocher ‘enclose in a bag’ (see poach)

definitions: illegally hunt or catch (game or fish) on land that is not one's own or in contravention of official protection

examples.text: 20 tigers are thought to have been poached from national parks
he might arrest you for poaching

shortDefinitions: illegally hunt or catch game or fish

definitions: take or acquire in an unfair or clandestine way

examples.text: employers risk having their newly trained workers poached by other companies

definitions: (in ball games) take a shot that a partner or teammate would have expected to take

examples.text: in doubles, you're poaching when you advance into your partner's territory

shortDefinitions: (in ball games) take partner's or teammate's shot

definitions: (of an animal) trample or cut up (turf) with its hoofs

examples.text: zero-grazing saves the fields from poaching

definitions: (of land) become sodden by being trampled

examples.text: if the ground is liable to poach the cows come inside
